case_name: Union of India v. Major Lala, Lt. Col. Khanna and Gupta

facts.text: Two of the appellants, Major Lala and Lt. Col. Khanna are Army officers and the appellant in the 3rd appeal, Gupta, is a businessman of Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the appellants, Major Lala and Lt. Col. Khanna are Army officers and the appellant in the 3rd appeal, Gupta, is a businessman of Gauhati. All of them were put up for trial before the Special Judge appointed under the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952.

facts.text: All three appellants were put up for trial before the Special Judge appointed under the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952.

anchor.surface_text: All of them were put up for trial before the Special Judge appointed under the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952. One charge which was ,common to all the three of them was that between June 1962 and January 1963 all of them agreed to companymit or cause to be companymitted offences under section 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act,

facts.text: Common charge: between June 1962 and January 1963 all three agreed to commit or cause to be committed offences under section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, and of cheating punishable under section 420 of the Indian Penal Code, punishable under section 120B IPC read with section 5(2) PC Act and section 420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: One charge which was ,common to all the three of them was that between June 1962 and January 1963 all of them agreed to companymit or cause to be companymitted offences under section 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, and of cheating punishable under section 420 of the Indian Penal Code, and these offences having been companymitted in pursuance of a companyspiracy were punishable under section 120B of the Indian Penal Code read with section 5  2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act and section 420 I.P.C.

facts.text: Mr. Gupta charged under section 420 IPC as well as section 511 read with section 420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gupta, the businessman was charged under section 420 I.P.C. as well as section 511 read with section 420 I.P.C. The two Army officers were also charged with offences under section 420 read with section 5  1   d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

facts.text: Two Army officers charged with offences under section 420 read with section 5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: The two Army officers were also charged with offences under section 420 read with section 5  1   d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act. The case was filed before the Special Judge on 28-6-1963 and the charge was framed on 13-2-65.

facts.text: Case filed before the Special Judge on 28-6-1963.

anchor.surface_text: The case was filed before the Special Judge on 28-6-1963 and the charge was framed on 13-2-65. After about 18 out of the 52 witnesses cited by the prosecution had been examined the three respondents filed petitions under section 561A read with section 439 of Code of Criminal Procedure before the High Court of Assam Nagaland on 28-3-68, 1-4-68 and 10-4- 68 respectively for quashing the charges.

facts.text: Charge framed on 13-2-1965.

anchor.surface_text: and the charge was framed on 13-2-65. After about 18 out of the 52 witnesses cited by the prosecution had been examined the three respondents filed petitions under section 561A read with section 439 of Code of Criminal Procedure before the High Court of Assam Nagaland on 28-3-68, 1-4-68 and 10-4- 68 respectively for quashing the charges.

facts.text: After examination of about 18 out of 52 prosecution witnesses, three respondents filed petitions under section 561A r/w 439 CrPC before High Court on 28-3-1968, 1-4-1968, 10-4-1968 to quash charges.

anchor.surface_text: After about 18 out of the 52 witnesses cited by the prosecution had been examined the three respondents filed petitions under section 561A read with section 439 of Code of Criminal Procedure before the High Court of Assam Nagaland on 28-3-68, 1-4-68 and 10-4- 68 respectively for quashing the charges. A learned Single Judge allowed these petitions on 23-5-1969 and quashed the charges and the proceedings before the learned Special Judge.

facts.text: Learned Single Judge of High Court allowed petitions and quashed charges and proceedings on 23-5-1969.

anchor.surface_text: A learned Single Judge allowed these petitions on 23-5-1969 and quashed the charges and the proceedings before the learned Special Judge. He did this on three grounds  1  that the officer who investigated the case was number companypetent to do so  2  that the offences that were being tried were numbercognizable and the Special Judge companyld number have taken companynizance of them without sanction under section 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure,

facts.text: High Court quashed on ground 1: investigating officer not competent.

anchor.surface_text: He did this on three grounds  1  that the officer who investigated the case was number companypetent to do so  2  that the offences that were being tried were numbercognizable and the Special Judge companyld number have taken companynizance of them without sanction under section 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and  3  that in view of the enormous length of time between 2-2-63, the date on which the case was registered and 1-4-68,

facts.text: High Court quashed on ground 2: offences non-cognizable, Special Judge could not take cognizance without sanction u/s 196A CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the offences that were being tried were numbercognizable and the Special Judge companyld number have taken companynizance of them without sanction under section 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and  3  that in view of the enormous length of time between 2-2-63, the date on which the case was registered and 1-4-68, upto which date some witness had been examined, the last witness having been examined on 15-1-67,

facts.text: High Court quashed on ground 3: enormous delay from 2-2-1963 (case registered) to 1-4-1968 (some witness examined), last witness on 15-1-1967, entails harassment.

anchor.surface_text: and  3  that in view of the enormous length of time between 2-2-63, the date on which the case was registered and 1-4-68, upto which date some witness had been examined, the last witness having been examined on 15-1-67, it entailed undue harassment to the accused persons and the proceedings have to be quashed to prevent further harassment, abuse of the process of the companyrt and vexation to the accused persons.

facts.text: Case registered on 2-2-1963.

anchor.surface_text: between 2-2-63, the date on which the case was registered and 1-4-68,

facts.text: Last witness examined on 15-1-1967.

anchor.surface_text: the last witness having been examined on 15-1-67,

facts.text: Appeals filed by Union of India by certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals have, therefore, been filed by the Union of India by certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Officer who investigated was Inspector of the Delhi Special Police Establishment.

anchor.surface_text: The officer was an Inspector of the Delhi Special Police Establishment.

facts.text: Inspector concerned obtained order of First Class Magistrate of Tezpur.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the Inspector companycerned had obtained the order of the First Class Magistrate of Tezpur.

facts.text: Order of Magistrate Tezpur dated 4-2-1963 permitting Inspector H.B.D. Baijal to investigate.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Magistrate runs as follows - Paper and F.I.R. seen. Shri H. B. D. Baijal, Inspector is permitted to investigate the case. There is an illegible signature with date 4-2- 63

facts.text: Superintendent of Special Police Establishment order dated 2-2-1963 entrusting investigation to Inspector Baijal.

anchor.surface_text: We have before us the order of the Superintendent of the Special Police Establishment dated 2-2-63 entrusting the investigation to Inspector Baijal and directing him to obtain the necessary permission from a companypetent Magistrate for doing so.

facts.text: Sanction under section 6 PC Act and section 197 CrPC accorded by Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: The sanction necessary under section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act and section 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure has been accorded by the Government of India.

facts.text: Case registered on 2-2-1963, order in Item 71 of papers under s.173 CrPC dated 4-2-1963.

anchor.surface_text: We have also been shown the papers relating to the prosecution, papers given to the accused under section 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Item 71 of those papers relates to the order of sanction dated 4-2-1963 given by the Magistrate of Tezpur authorizing the Inspector of the P.E. to investigate.

facts.text: Respondents took nearly three years before moving High Court for quashing.

anchor.surface_text: It may incidentally be mentioned that the respondents took nearly three years before they moved the High Court for quashing the charges and are, thus, to a companysiderable extent responsible for the delay.

facts.text: Appeals are from judgment and order dated May 23, 1969 of Assam and Nagaland High Court in Cr. Rev. Nos. 36, 39 and 46 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by certificate from the. judgment and order dated May 23, 1969 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court at Gauhati in Cr. Rev. Nos. 36, 39 and 46 of 1968. 82 0 Mookherjee, Avtar Singh, G. Das, S. P. Nayar and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

arguments.claim: under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act no officer below DSP could investigate or arrest without warrant, so not cognizable as any police officer cannot arrest without warrant

anchor.surface_text: The argument which appealed to the learned Judge of the High Court was that as under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act no officer below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police could investigate or make any arrest without a warrant in respect of offences punishable under section 161, 165 or 165A I.P.C. and section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, they were not offences for which any police officer can arrest without warrant,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ture is number Affected by either S. 3 or S. 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act. The requirement that in a companynizable offence, a police office

arguments.court_reasoning: Under s.6 CLA, s.7(3) CLA, s.235/239 CrPC joinder allowed; precedent in Kandimalla Subbiah

arguments.claim: order under s.5A sufficient if magistrate has territorial jurisdiction over place where any part of offence took place

anchor.surface_text: All that is necessary is that the Magistrate who makes the order under section 5A should have territorial jurisdiction over the place where any part of the ingredients of the offence took place. That criterion is amply satisfied in this case.

arguments.claim: accepting need for orders from every magistrate would be absurd for conspiracy spread over country

anchor.surface_text: On principle also such a contention seems to be devoid of any substance. The offence of conspiracy or for that matter any other offence might consist of a series of acts and incidents spread over the whole country. ... To accept this contention would be to hold that the Police should go to every Magistrate within whose jurisdiction some part of the conspiracy or one of the ingredients of the offence has taken place.

arguments.claim: offences under ss.161,165,165A IPC and s.5 PC Act are cognizable per Schedule II CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Under Schedule II of the Code of Criminal Procedure offences under sections 161 to 165 of the Indian Penal Code are shown as cognizable offences. ... Under section 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act the sentence may extend to seven years. Therefore, an offence under section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act is according to the provision in Schedule II to the Code of Criminal Procedure a cognizable offence.

arguments.claim: s.5A PC Act does not make offences non-cognizable; only limits class of competent officers

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the mere fact that under the Prevention of Corruption Act certain restrictions are placed as to the officers who are competent to investigate into offences mentioned in section 5A would not make those offences any the less cognizable offences. The words notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure found at the beginning of section 5A merely carve out a limited exemption

arguments.claim: s.5 CrPC applies to PC Act offences subject to special enactments

anchor.surface_text: Under section 5 of the Code of Criminal Procedure all offences under the Indian Penal Code shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the provisions therein contained. Also, all offences under any other law which would include the Prevention of Corruption Act shall be investigated, inquired into, tried, and otherwise dealt with according to the same provisions but subject to any enactment

arguments.claim: respondents responsible for delay by taking nearly three years to move High Court

anchor.surface_text: It may incidentally be mentioned that the respondents took nearly three years before they moved the High Court for quashing the charges and are, thus, to a considerable extent responsible for the delay.

arguments.claim: Gupta can be tried together under s.6 CLA Act, s.7(3), s.235/239 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Under section 6 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952 the Special Judge may try any conspiracy ... and under sub-section 3 of section 7 ... Under section 235 ... under section 239 persons accused of the same offence committed in the course of the same transaction

arguments.claim: precedent in Chinnappa supports any First Class Magistrate in district can issue order

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge referred to and relied upon the decision in Chinnappa v. State of Mysore 1 . It was decided in that case that any First Class Magistrate appointed in a district can issue orders under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act for investigation of a case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: btained the order of the First Class Magistrate of Tezpur. The argument before the High Court, which was accepted by the learned Judge, was that as th

arguments.court_reasoning: But does not require order from every magistrate where part of offence occurred

arguments.claim: offences cognizable even if investigated under s.5A PC Act; cites various High Court precedents

anchor.surface_text: We may not refer to certain decisions of various High Courts on this point. In Taj Khan v. The State ... In Ram Rijhumal v. The State ... In Gulabsingh v. State ... The learned Judges specifically dissented from the decision in Union of India v. Mahesh Chandra

arguments.claim: joint trial allowed as per Kandimalla Subbiah

anchor.surface_text: In The State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kandimalla Subbaih Anr. 1 this Court observed No doubt, the offence mentioned in charge No. 1 is alleged to have been committed not by just one person but by all the accused ... Clearly, therefore, all the accused persons could be tried together

holdings.text: The investigating officer was properly authorized to investigate the case as he obtained the order from the First Class Magistrate of Tezpur who had territorial jurisdiction over the place where part of the offence took place.

anchor.surface_text: The argument before the High Court, which was accepted by the learned Judge, was that as the offences of conspiracy were alleged to have been committed both at Tezpur as well as at Gauhati, the investigation based on the order of the Tezpur Magistrate alone was not a proper one. In other words, the argument was that unless the Inspector had been authorized to investigate not only by the First Class Magistrate of Tezpur but also by the First Class of Gauhati district, he could not have done so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate order from one with territorial jurisdiction over any part sufficient; rejecting need for multiple orders; documents confirm genuineness.

holdings.text: Offences under sections 161, 165, 165A IPC and section 5 of PC Act are cognizable offences regardless of investigating officer's rank or section 5A order.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether offences under section 161, 165 and 165A of the Indian Penal Code and section 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable or non- cognizable offences. This becomes important for the purpose of deciding whether a sanction under section 196A is necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Schedule II CrPC and s.4(1)(f); s.5A limits officer class but does not alter cognizability; s.5 CrPC applies subject to special provisions; High Court precedents support.

holdings.text: No sanction under section 196A CrPC required as offences are cognizable.

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, of the need for a sanction under section 196A does not arise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from cognizability holding; no re-investigation needed.

holdings.text: Enormous delay does not warrant quashing proceedings to prevent harassment or abuse of process.

anchor.surface_text: It may incidentally be mentioned that the respondents took nearly three years before they moved the High Court for quashing the charges and are, thus, to a considerable extent responsible for the delay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondents responsible for much delay; other grounds invalid so no re-investigation or further delay.

holdings.text: Businessman Gupta can be tried jointly with Army officers before Special Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of Mr. Gupta it was argued that he cannot be tried along with the two Army officers. Under section 6 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952 the Special Judge may try any conspiracy to commit or any attempt to commit or any abetment of any of the offences punishable under section 161, 165 or 165A of the Indian Penal Code or sub-section  2  of section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 & 7(3) CLA Act, s.235 & 239 CrPC allow joinder for same transaction/conspiracy; precedent in Kandimalla Subbiah.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge referred to and relied upon the decision in Chinnappa v. State of Mysore 1 . It was decided in that case that any First Class Magistrate appointed in a district can issue orders under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act for investigation of a case. From this the learned Single Judge drew the conclusion that in respect of an offence said to have been committed at Gauhati as well as at Tezpur the order of the Tezpur Magistrate was not enough.

precedents.cited_proposition: any First Class Magistrate appointed in a district can issue orders under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act for investigation of a case

precedents.citation: Chatterjee v. Delhi Special Police Establishment 2

anchor.surface_text: He also relied upon the decision of the High Court of Assam and Nagaland in Chatterjee v. Delhi Special Police Establishment 2 . This decision has been upheld by this Court in Union of India v. B. N. Ananthapadmanabhiah 3 . But that was a case of a Delhi Magistrate sanctioning an investigation of offences committed in Assam and it was held that such an order was not valid.

precedents.case_name: Chatterjee v Delhi Special Police Establishment
precedents.cited_proposition: order of Delhi Magistrate not valid for investigation of offences committed in Assam

precedents.citation: Union of India v. B. N. Ananthapadmanabhiah 3

anchor.surface_text: This decision has been upheld by this Court in Union of India v. B. N. Ananthapadmanabhiah 3 . But that was a case of a Delhi Magistrate sanctioning an investigation of offences committed in Assam and it was held that such an order was not valid. That decision is not authority for the proposition that where an offence is committed in more than one place the order of every Magistrate within whose jurisdiction the offence or part of the offence was committed was necessary

precedents.case_name: Union of India v B N Ananthapadmanabhiah
precedents.cited_proposition: Delhi Magistrate's order invalid for Assam offences

precedents.citation: G. K. Apte v. Union of India

anchor.surface_text: The Assam High Court seems to have taken a line of its own in this matter. In G. K. Apte v. Union of India curiously enough the Bench, of which the learned Judge who dealt with this case was a member, took the view that though an offence under section 161 is a cognizable offence, if investigations were made under section 156 of the Code of Criminal Procedure there would be no need for a sanction under section 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure

precedents.case_name: G K Apte v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: offence under section 161 cognizable under s156 CrPC but non-cognizable under s5A PC Act requiring s196A sanction

precedents.citation: H. N. Rishbud Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi 2

anchor.surface_text: For this conclusion the decision of this Court in H. N. Rishbud Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi 2 was relied upon. We can see nothing in that case to support this conclusion. Nor are we able to see how if the investigation into an offence of misconduct punishable under section 5 is done by a police officer of high rank the offence is cognizable and if investigated by an officer of a lower rank it is non-cognizable.

precedents.case_name: H N Rishbud Inder Singh v State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: relied upon for distinction between investigations under s156 and s5A

anchor.surface_text: We may not refer to certain decisions of various High Courts on this point. In Taj Khan v. The State it was held The fact that the power to investigate or to arrest without warrant has been circumscribed by certain conditions which conditions were clearly provided for the purpose of safeguarding public servants from harassment at the hands of subordinate police officers under the proviso. to S. 3 of the said Act cannot lead to the conclusion that such offence is non-cognizable.

precedents.cited_proposition: circumscribing investigation/arrest power under PC Act does not make offence non-cognizable
precedents.cited_holding: fact that power to investigate or arrest without warrant circumscribed does not make offence non-cognizable

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Rijhumal v. The State 2 it was held The provisions of S. 3, Prevention of Corruption Act can only have one meaning, and the meaning is that an offence under S. 165A of the Penal Code has to be deemed to be a cognizable- offence for the purpose of ,the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.cited_proposition: offence under s165A IPC is cognizable offence for CrPC purposes despite s5A PC Act
precedents.cited_holding: provisions of s3 PC Act deem s165A cognizable

anchor.surface_text: In Gulabsingh v. State it was held that offence under S. 161, I.P.C. is a cognizable offence. Its nature is not Affected by either S. 3 or S. 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act. The requirement that in a cognizable offence, a police officer should be able to arrest without warrant, is without any limitation and section 5A cannot be split. up to mean that an offence can be cognizable in reference to one officer and non in reference to another.

precedents.cited_proposition: s161 IPC cognizable unaffected by s3 or s5A PC Act; cannot be cognizable for some officers only
precedents.cited_holding: offence under s161 IPC is cognizable; s5A does not change that

precedents.citation: Union of India v. Mahesh Chandra

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges specifically dissented from the decision in Union of India v. Mahesh Chandra . In Public Prosecutor v. Shaik Sheriff 2 it was held that these offences cannot be treated as non-cognizable offences when investigated by an officer below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police simply on the ground that such investigation cannot be done without the order of a Presidency Magistrate or a Magistrate of the First Class.

precedents.case_name: Union of India v Mahesh Chandra
precedents.cited_proposition: offences cognizable for DSP+ but non-cognizable for lower officers

anchor.surface_text: In Public Prosecutor v. Shaik Sheriff 2 it was held that these offences cannot be treated as non-cognizable offences when investigated by an officer below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police simply on the ground that such investigation cannot be done without the order of a Presidency Magistrate or a Magistrate of the First Class. In the same way, offences under section 5 of the Act cannot be treated as non-cognizable even when investigated by a low rank officer.

precedents.cited_proposition: PC Act offences not non-cognizable merely because lower officers need magistrate order
precedents.cited_holding: cannot treat as non-cognizable when investigated by lower officer

precedents.citation: Union of India v. Mahesh Chandra supra

anchor.surface_text: They also referred to the decision in Union of India v. Mahesh Chandra supra to the effect that an offence under S. 161 I.P.C. and under sub. s. 2 of S. 5, Prevention of Corruption Act is cognizable so far as officers of the rank of a Deputy Superintendent of Police and above are concerned, but so far as the officers below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police are concerned the said offences are non-cognizable

precedents.case_name: Union of India v Mahesh Chandra
precedents.cited_proposition: offences cognizable for higher officers, non-cognizable for lower

precedents.citation: The State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kandimalla Subbaih Anr. 1

anchor.surface_text: In The State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kandimalla Subbaih Anr. 1 this Court observed No doubt, the offence mentioned in charge No. 1 is alleged to have been committed not by just one person but by all the accused and the question is whether all these persons can be joint tried in respect of all these offences. To this kind of charge S. 239 would apply. This section provides that the following persons may be charged and tried together, namely 1 persons accused of the same offence committed in the course of the same transaction

precedents.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v Kandimalla Subbaih
precedents.cited_proposition: public servant and private persons can be jointly tried for conspiracy/abetment offences under Criminal Law Amendment Act
precedents.cited_holding: accused can be tried together under s239 CrPC; special judge can try other offences under s7(3)

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support defeaters
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of opinion that the offences under sections 161, 165 and 165A of the Indian Penal Code and section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable offences and there is no question of their being cognizable if investigated by a Deputy Superintendent of Police and non-cognizable when investigated by an Inspector of Police.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order quashing charges held unjustified as investigator was competent, offences cognizable, no sanction under s.196A CrPC required, and delay partly attributable to respondents; Gupta can be tried jointly
directions: Proceedings before Special Judge to continue

edges.explanation: Holding directly resolves the issue of whether the investigating officer was properly authorized by stating he obtained a valid magistrate order.

anchor.surface_text: The argument before the High Court, which was accepted by the learned Judge, was that as the offences of conspiracy were alleged to have been committed both at Tezpur as well as at Gauhati, the investigation based on the order of the Tezpur Magistrate alone was not a proper one. In other words, the argument was that unless the Inspector had been authorized to investigate not only by the First Class Magistrate of Tezpur but also by the First Class of Gauhati district, he could not have done so.

We are, therefore, clearly of opinion that the offences under sections 161, 165 and 165A of the Indian Penal Code and section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable offences and there is no question of their being cognizable if investigated by a Deputy Superintendent of Police and non-cognizable when investigated by an Inspector of Police.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether offences under section 161, 165 and 165A of the Indian Penal Code and section 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable or non- cognizable offences. This becomes important for the purpose of deciding whether a sanction under section 196A is necessary.

We are, therefore, clearly of opinion that the offences under sections 161, 165 and 165A of the Indian Penal Code and section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable offences and there is no question of their being cognizable if investigated by a Deputy Superintendent of Police and non-cognizable when investigated by an Inspector of Police.

edges.explanation: h2 holds cognizable regardless of rank/s.5A, distinguishing p11's rank-based distinction

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, of the need for a sanction under section 196A does not arise.

We are, therefore, clearly of opinion that the offences under sections 161, 165 and 165A of the Indian Penal Code and section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable offences and there is no question of their being cognizable if investigated by a Deputy Superintendent of Police and non-cognizable when investigated by an Inspector of Police.

anchor.surface_text: It may incidentally be mentioned that the respondents took nearly three years before they moved the High Court for quashing the charges and are, thus, to a considerable extent responsible for the delay.

We are, therefore, clearly of opinion that the offences under sections 161, 165 and 165A of the Indian Penal Code and section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable offences and there is no question of their being cognizable if investigated by a Deputy Superintendent of Police and non-cognizable when investigated by an Inspector of Police.

edges.explanation: The holding directly addresses and affirmatively resolves the issue of whether businessman Mr. Gupta can be tried jointly with the two Army officers before the Special Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of Mr. Gupta it was argued that he cannot be tried along with the two Army officers. Under section 6 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952 the Special Judge may try any conspiracy to commit or any attempt to commit or any abetment of any of the offences punishable under section 161, 165 or 165A of the Indian Penal Code or sub-section  2  of section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act,

We are, therefore, clearly of opinion that the offences under sections 161, 165 and 165A of the Indian Penal Code and section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act are cognizable offences and there is no question of their being cognizable if investigated by a Deputy Superintendent of Police and non-cognizable when investigated by an Inspector of Police.
